EE: i just don't know why i've never heard about it
ER: neither do i!

They have been assigned the roles of persuader (ER) and persuadee (EE), and they are discussing Save the Children (STC), a charitable organization.
STC is an NGO founded in the UK in 1919 to improve children's lives globally.
ER is attempting to convince EE to make a donation to STC.
Your task is to determine the real intention of the last utterance based on the conversation.

ER: I think out of all charities saving the children is most important one as children make the future.
ER: Hope you agree
EE: I definitely agree
ER: this is good as you agree with opinion as everyone should do the same
EE: Yes - providing funding for children is a top priority, whatever the need may be
ER: I usually put some money for this cause yearly
EE: What kind of children's charities do you think are the most important?
ER: I think children below the poverty line is most important
EE: Yes - someone needs to be looking out for those children!
ER: I say, if you have enough than give to others. basic education is very important to have a good future
EE: Important to make sure their basic needs are met too -- food, clothing and shelter
ER: what is the good amout you think
EE: It depends, should this be a monthly donation or annual?
ER: annually one time payment
EE: Ok, sounds good.
ER: I think a range between $100 - $250 would be appropriate
ER: would you like to donate something from your task payment for this cause
EE: Not without knowing the exact organization
ER: URL Also I will donate the same amount whatever you decide
EE: I am unclear as to whether or not this is a real donation or just discussion for the sake of the task
ER: Whatever you want to donate from your task money
EE: I will donate 20 cents

Q: Explain whether the last utterance clearly conveys the speaker's intention. If the last utterance clearly conveys the speaker's intent, what was that? If not, why did the speaker say it that way, and what intention was implied through the utterance? Based on that premise, which option among A through D is the most appropriate option that represents the intention of the last utterance? (D) EE shows willingness to donate or to discuss the charity.
A: Let's think step by step.

They have been assigned the roles of persuader (ER) and persuadee (EE), and they are discussing Save the Children (STC), a charitable organization.
STC is an NGO founded in the UK in 1919 to improve children's lives globally.
ER is attempting to convince EE to make a donation to STC.
Your task is to determine the real intention of the last utterance based on the conversation.

ER: Hello there, how are you doing today?
EE: I'm great, thanks. How are you?
ER: I'm doing swell, thanks for asking! So how do you feel about children?
EE: I love children. I believe they are our future and should be taken care of in the best possible way.
ER: That's great! I happen to agree! Do you have any children yourself, or do you plan to in the future?
EE: I do not have children of my own and am not able to have them. I am contemplating adoption for the future.
ER: Oh, that's wonderful!
ER: So many kids out there need a home, after all! There are so many issues today with children, all over the world! For instance, did you know that in the first two months of 2018 alone, over 1k children were killed or injured in intensifying violence?
EE: Wow, that is a staggering amount.
EE: I did not know that. I am a big fan of organizations who take care of the needs of hurt children.
ER: Oh?
ER: That\'s awesome!
ER: I assume you\'ve heard about the organization called "Save the Children" then?
EE: I have!
EE: They seem to be doing a good job.
ER: That, they do! Did you know they've won over 7 different awards for their charitable work?
ER: As a former foster kid, it makes me happy to see this place bring such awareness to the issues and needs of our young.
EE: I am not surprised to hear that at all. Children should not have to do through so much tragedy and devastation at such young ages. It is great that others are looking out for them.
ER: Absolutely!
ER: In fact, you can even help!
ER: If you want to make a small donation from your task payment, I'm sure it would be greatly appreciated!
ER: You can donate just a few cents, or even the whole amount of your final payout if you choose!
EE: I probably will do that.
EE: If everyone did something, it helps the bigger overall picture and they are so worth it.
ER: Absolutely!
ER: I mean, we already spend money on small snacks or a coffee we could forgo, why not give it to a charitable cause?
ER: How noble of you!
EE: I just know that if I were a child in need, I would be grateful for all the help I could get.
ER: Absolutely!
ER: I remember being in a group home as a kid, and a bunch of ladies had made blankets and hats for us. I still have the blanket I was made to this day!
ER: A little goes a long way :)
EE: Wow, that is so good to hear.
EE: I'm sure it is not easy for organizations to get charitable work done but I am grateful they try and that others get involved.
EE: Kuddos to them!
ER: Yeah, it really is humbling to watch society ban together and help each other!

Q: Explain whether the last utterance clearly conveys the speaker's intention. If the last utterance clearly conveys the speaker's intent, what was that? If not, why did the speaker say it that way, and what intention was implied through the utterance? Based on that premise, which option among A through D is the most appropriate option that represents the intention of the last utterance? Answer Choices: (A) ER asks EE to donate more. (B) ER asks EE for their time or permission to discuss charities. (C) ER apologizes for inconvenience or intrusion. (D) ER praises or promotes the good deeds of STC.
A: Let's think step by step.

They have been assigned the roles of persuader (ER) and persuadee (EE), and they are discussing Save the Children (STC), a charitable organization.
STC is an NGO founded in the UK in 1919 to improve children's lives globally.
ER is attempting to convince EE to make a donation to STC.
Your task is to determine the real intention of the last utterance based on the conversation.

ER: Hello how are you doing today?
EE: I'm good, how are you?
ER: I am well. Just enjoying the sunny day and trying to help out a charity I am working on, Save the Children.
EE: I wish I had some sun. Please tell me more about this charity
ER: This charity is n international non-governmental organization that promotes children's rights, provides relief and helps support children in developing countries.
ER: I have recently donated some money to it.
ER: Would you be interested in how much I donated?
EE: Yes please.
EE: And also, was the donation mandatory or voluntary?
ER: I donate about $15 a month and it is all voluntary.
ER: I rather put my money into this charity then church offering because I know it directly helps children.
ER: Would you like to know how I know it helps?
EE: That sounds like a reasonable amount. Sure, tell me more about how it's used
ER: A year ago, I saw kid begging on the street who look really hungry.
ER: I was about to give him some money until a representative for "Save the Children" walked ahead of me and help this kid out.
ER: This person took them to their facility and provided food, shelter, and clothing. A month later I saw the kid was healthier, happy, and cleaner. I was so impress I decided to make a donation.
ER: Would you be interested in a donation?
EE: Wow. Nice story.
EE: I'm very particular about who I donate to so I'd need more information
ER: Understand.
EE: About how many people a month does the charity help?
ER: Since it is international it helps more then 1000's of kids per month.
EE: And is there a minimum amount required per month (like on of those sponsor a kid charities) or can it be just a one time donation?
ER: No minimum, can be a one time donation.
EE: That sounds doable.
EE: Do you know by any chance if this is a registered charity?
EE: I want to make sure not all the money is going to the staff via salaries
